subSection.paragraph: Review

paragraph.docTitle: Natural sucrose esters: Perspectives on the chemical and physiological use of an under investigated chemical class of compounds

subSection.paragraph:
Jorge Andrés Mora Vargas a , Julieth Orduña Ortega a,b , Gustavo Metzker a , Jesus Eliecer Larrahondo b
, Mauricio Boscolo
a,
∗

collectionCode.name: Field Museum of Natural History, Botany Department

document.paragraph: The present review describes the chemistry and physiological properties of the sucrose esters (SEs) obtained from natural or synthetic pathways, with emphasis on those that have aliphatic and phenylpropanoid substituents on their sucrose moiety. Synthesis, extraction and characterization methods for the SEs and NSEs are discussed in terms of synthetic procedures, separation techniques and spectroscopic methods. The physiological properties are discussed taking into account the nature of the substituent groups and their regiochemistry (position and number of substitutions) on the sucrose moiety.

heading.emphasis: 1. Sucrose, sucrose esters (SEs) and natural sucrose esters (NSEs)

subSection.paragraph: NSEs are characterized by the esterification of the different hydroxyl groups of sucrose with carboxylic acids, with different degrees of substitution resulting in a large number of regioisomers which generates a wide range of chemical and biological properties. Originally, NSEs are extracted from plants with water, as well as, solvents such as methanol, ethanol, petroleum ether, dichloromethane, hexane and ethyl acetate ( Bernal et al., 2018 ; Franco et al., 2014 ; Zhang et al., 2016a , 2017 bib_Zhang_et_al_2016a).
SEs and NSEs are both characterized by their low toxicity in humans, as well as being environmentally friendly and biodegradable

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Chemical structure of sucrose.

subSection.paragraph: Different catalysts have been used in transesterification reaction for the synthesis of SEs. For instance, Huang et al. (2010) determined the influence of potassium carbonate on the production of sucrose caprylate. The results showed that when the amount of catalyst was 13% potassium carbonate in relation to the moles of the starting methyl ester, the yields were 75% higher than those obtained when other catalysts such as monosodium hydrogen phosphate and a mixture of potassium carbonate and polyethylene glycol (PEG-400) were used.

Ferrer et al. (2000) studied the synthesis of laureate sucrose using different catalysts, with sodium bisphosphate finding high selectivity in the production of mono-substituted isomers but low yields in the transesterification reaction. The use of Celite as catalyst provides conversion close to 30% in 24 h, with high selectivity in mono-esters. Disodium hydrogen phosphate (Na 2 HPO 4 )/Celite was employed as catalysts to provide a conversion of 60% to mono-esters and 40% to diesters, with high selectivity for mono-esters directed toward the secondary hydroxyl OH-2 (80%) and OH-3 (20%). Also, it is reported that the use of γ- alumina as catalyst in this reaction caused negligible acylation of sucrose.

Another approach is the combination of homogenous catalysis with acoustic cavitation. Hang et al. (2017) improved the production of mono-substituted SEs by testing different parameters of ultrasonic irradiation in transesterification synthesis with ethyl esters of fatty acids. The authors concluded that mono-substitution (92%) is favored with 2:1 sucrose to methyl ester molar ratio, and that it is possible to achieve reaction rates of up to 73% with selectivity in hydroxyl OH-6 and OH- 6'.

Heterogeneous catalysis has also been studied in transesterification reactions for SEs synthesis ( Fig. 3a ). However, the reaction employing this type of catalysis is kinetically unfavorable as it requires high reaction temperatures, which further creates the problem of possible sucrose degradation by caramelization reactions while providing chemical and physical changes in the products ( Jiang et al., 2008 ). The utilization of heterogeneous catalysis were performed by Kharchafi et al. (2005) using polystyrene, non-porous silica, and mesoporous silica functionalized with guanidine. These catalysts proved to have strong basic catalytic sites for the transesterification of sucrose with different fatty acids using DMSO as solvent, with yields above 92% and selectivity of 90% for mono-substituted sucrose esters. Recently, Sasayama et al. (2018) studied the production of fatty acid SEs using strong basic ion exchange resin, showing high catalytic activity under conditions of mild temperature and pressure in a continuous flow reactor. The ion exchange resin holds a high concentration of absorbed sucrose, making the continuous production of SEs possible in short residence periods in the reactor (approx. 1.5 h) without secondary reactions such as saponification. Feuge et al. (1970) described the production of SEs derived from fatty acids using the reaction between molten sucrose and carboxylic acid derived esters within the temperature range of 170–187 ̊ C , obtaining poly-substituted esters as products. However, this procedure presents the disadvantage of obtaining a highly viscous mixture, limiting the miscibility of the reagents which promote the formation of a solid interface, thus decreasing the extension of the reaction. Also, this methodology is not selective as it yields a complex product mixture ( Fitremann et al., 2007 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Examples of SEs synthesis. (A) protection and unprotection approach and (B) biocatalysis approach.

subSection.paragraph:
The total synthesis of phenylpropanoid SEs, as reported by Panda et al. (2012) , was from the reaction of 2,1’:4,6-di-
O
-isopropylidene sucrose and p -acetoxyferuloyl chloride, producing tetra-acylated derivative with yields ranging from 30% to 44%. The tetra-acylated derivate were subjected to acetal deprotection using 60% aqueous acetic acid at 80 ̊ C . The products, SEs, were formed by deacetylation reaction with piperidine-95% ethanol ( Fig. 3b ). As presented above, the phenylpropanoid SEs are important classes of natural compounds with different biological activities.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. Examples of SEs synthesis. (A) heterogeneous catalysis approach and (B) total synthesis of phenylpropanoid SEs.

subSection.paragraph:
The extraction of NSEs can be done from leaves, fruits, or other parts of plants, and it is usually necessary done via solvent extraction with a Soxhlet extractor. Different solvents such as ethanol, dichloromethane, petroleum ether, and methanol has been used ( Buta et al., 1993 ; Kiem et al., 2008 ; Sun et al., 2000 ). The extract obtained is concentrated by evaporation to obtain a mixture of different products, and the NSEs purified by liquid-liquid partition using solvents of different polarities (n-butanol, methanol, chloroform, among others) or by chromatographic techniques ( Kiem et al., 2008 ; Sun et al., 2000 ; Zhu et al., 2013 ). For instance, Masum et al. (2019) extracted phenylpropanoid NSEs from
Persicaria orientalis
. In brief, 1.5 kg of root of
P. orientalis
was treated with methanol (MeOH) for 24 h at room temperature and this process was repeated three-fold. Posteriorly, the solvent was removed under reduced pressure to give MeOH extract ( 0.105 kg ), to which different solvents of increasing polarities (hexane, ethyl acetate and ethanol) was added in order to purify the NSEs. The NSEs in each solvent fraction was purified by chromatography, yielding 40–60 mg of NSEs.

Another phenylpropanoid NSEs from
Polygonum hydropiper
was extracted by similar methodology by Van Kiem et al. (2008) . Briefly, 3.0 kg of leaves and stems were submitted to extraction with hot methanol (three-fold) and the obtained extract ( 0.15 kg ) was suspended in water, and then partitioned with chloroform and n-butanol in that order. The organic phases produced by n-butanol ( 0.02 kg ) and chloroform ( 0.03 kg ) fractions were purified by silica gel column chromatography using a discontinuous gradient of increasing polarity from chloroform, methanol and water, yielding 15–60 mg of NSEs.

Ashraf-Khorassani et al. (2008) employed supercritical fluid for the NSEs extraction from Turkish tobacco. The NSEs were isolated from tobacco leaf ( 2 g ) using supercritical CO 2 at different temperature and pressure (optimal condition: 100% of CO 2 , 100 ̊ C and 250 atm). The products obtained were partitioned with hexane and methanol-water (80%–20%) mixture. The methanol-water fraction was re-extracted using hexane and chloroform. In comparison with conventional extraction methodologies, the use of supercritical fluids decreased the number of stages in the purification and isolation process. However, this method provides similar extraction percentage of NSEs (determinate by GC-MS) when compared to conventional methods. Regarding synthetic SEs purification, this is still a challenge, however, other isolation methods have been commonly used.

The chemical characterization of SEs and NSEs is a challenging task, and this is due to the possible presence of various regioisomers giving rise to a large number of possible structures. On this perspective, the combination of the various techniques such as liquid or gas chromatography (LC or GC, respectively) hyphenated or not with mass spectrometry (MS), and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) are used to elucidate the SEs and NSEs structures.

The utilization of LC for the isolation of SEs and NSEs employing different system conditions has been studied since it is not necessary to carry out sample derivatization prior to the analysis. Several stationary phases including C 18, C 8 and modified silica-based have been used to perform the regioisomers separation.

Depending on the type of organic acid (aliphatic or aromatic) substituent on the sucrose moiety, the type of detector coupled with LC is chosen. SEs and NSEs substituted with long- or short-chain fatty acids are not usually detected by UV absorption, therefore, detectors such as evaporative light scattering (ELSD), refractive index (RI), charged aerosol detector ( CAD ) and LC-MS are used with the latter used mainly for the identification of SEs and NSEs.

For example, Pedersen et al. (2003) determined the degree of conversion in the synthesis of sucrose laurate using C 18 column coupled with a RI detector using methanol/water as the mobile phase. Molinier et al. (2003) used a silica-based column modified with aminopropyl coupled with a RI detector for the analysis of group migration on the sucrose in the transesterification reaction, and separation of regioisomers produced in the synthesis of aliphatic SEs.

Zhu et al. (2009) used a C 8 column coupled with ELSD for the identification of SEs with long-chain fatty acid with different degree of substitution using methanol: tetrahydrofuran and water in gradient elution as the mobile phase. Other studies for the separation and identification of commercial aliphatic SEs with different degree of substitution were conducted by Moh et al. (2000) using a C 18 column coupled with ELSD or MS detector using methanol/water as the mobile phase.

Other methodology for the identification of the regioisomeric distribution in mixture of SEs was performed by Christiansen et al. (2011) using C 8 column coupled with a charged aerosol detector ( CAD ). The separation was carried out using acetonitrile: water as the mobile phase in gradient elution mode. The sucrose ester was dissolved in HCl solution (pH 1.0), and analyzed by LC-CAD. The results revealed the presence of eight regioisomers of sucrose mono-laurate.

On the other hand, the use of LC-MS for the identification of SEs and NSEs has been reported. Among the main ions found for acyl sucrose are the ones generated by the glycosidic bond cleavage which yields pyranosyl and furanosyl fragments ( Ghosh and Jones, 2017 ). For example, de Koster et al. (1993) employed Fast Atom Bombardment (FAB) for the ionization of sucrose monocaprate and monolaurate in the presence of Na + ions (saturated NaCl solution). The result showed a peak in the positive mode of sucrose monocaprate [M + Na] + at m / z 519. Additionally, in the MS spectrum, there were observed ions at m / z 339 and 357 formed by the loss of C 6 H 10 O 5 on the glycosidic bond cleavage. For the sucrose monolaurate, similar results were observed. The most intense peak was showed in the positive ion mass spectrum for the cation [M + Na] + at m / z 547.

Wei et al. (2014) identified sucrose 6-acetate synthetized employing the biocatalysis by ESI-LC-MS in positive mode. The result showed a peak of [M + Na] + at m / z 407, and two typical fragment ions, [M– C 6 H 10 O 5 + Na] + at m / z 245 and [M– C 8 H 14 O 7 + Na] + at m/z 185, formed by the glycosidic bond cleavage.

On the other hand, Lie et al. (2015) analyzed 6- and 6′-
O
-lauroyl sucrose regioisomers by Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization (MALDI), time-of-flight (TOF) MS, and High-Resolution Mass Spectrometry (HR-MS). The MALDI-TOF-MS showed the signal correspondent for the molecular ion adducts with Na + and K + at m / z 547 and 563, respectively, and was confirmed by HR-MS. Also, in both regioisomers two characteristics signal were found. The first molecular ion is found at m / z 345 and it corresponds to glycosyl fatty acid ester ions [M–Glucose + H ] + or [M–Fructose + H ] + formed by the glycosidic bond cleavage and subsequent loss of C 6 H 12 O
6 in
the sucrose. The second molecular ion is found at m/ z 273 formed by the loss of three CH 2 O molecules in [M–Glucose + H ] + or [M–Fructose + H ] + to form [M– C 9 H 18 O 9 + H ] + . In addition, for 6- O- lauroyl sucrose, two additional signals are found at m / z 439 and 409, corresponding to the ions adducts [M– C 3 H 8 O 4 + Na] + and [M– C 4 H 10 O 5 + Na] + , respectively. The neutral loss of three CH 2 O groups and one H 2 O in the [ C 24 H 44 O 12 + Na] + formed the first molecular ions. Also, the additional loss of one CH 2 O formed the second molecular ion.

In addition, the regioisomeric distribution and structure identification of SEs with different long-chain fatty acids as substituents can be performed by LC-MS. Zhu et al. (2013) employed a C 18 column coupled to MS detector with electrospray ionization interface (ESI) for the separation and identification of NSEs extracted from oriental tobacco leaves using methanol/water in gradient of elution. Pérez-Victoria et al. (2007) used mixtures of commercial isomers of sucrose monolaurate, monodecanoate and monopalmitate for the identification of regioisomeric distribution in the sample by LC-ESI-MS. A C 18 column at 40 ̊ C was used as the stationary phase and the SEs eluted in isocratic mode with an acetonitrile-water mixture serving as the mobile phase.

heading.emphasis: 4.2. Gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry (GC-MS)

subSection.paragraph:
The SEs and NSEs can be hydrolyzed for the release and identification of substituents derivatized from long-chain fatty acids. Different methodologies have been employed for the hydrolysis of SEs. For example, hydrolysis of the aliphatic SEs with KOH in methanol or HCl produces fatty acids, which can be derivatized (methylated) for further analysis by GC techniques ( Okumura et al., 2011 ; Simonovska et al., 2006 ; Zhang et al., 2016a , 2016b ). Zhang et al. (2016a , 2016b ) determined the fatty acid present as substitutes in NSEs extracted by
Physalis philadelphica
. The result showed the presence of the methyl ester of decanoic acid ( m/ z 186) as substituents on the NSEs.

The derivatization of SEs and NSEs such as trimethylsilyl (TMS) derivatives have been used to derivatize the non-acylated hydroxyl groups ( Ashraf-Khorassani et al., 2016 ; Karrer and Herberg, 1992 ; Ruiz-Matute et al., 2011 ). For example, Hali ń ski and Stepnowski (2013) determined the main NSEs extracted from
Nicotiana tabacum
. After isolation and purification of the NSEs, these compounds were derivatized with
N, O
-bis(trimethylsilyl)trifluoroacetamide (BSTFA) and trimethylchlorosilane (TMCS). The GC-MS analysis showed characteristic ions at m / z 443, 457, 471, 485 and 499, indicated the presence of tetraacyl glucose and ions at m / z 451, 437 and 361, and the presence of tetra-TMS-fructose for the NSEs from
N. tabacum
.

In regarding to the regiochemistry characterization of the SEs and NSEs, the acylated hydroxyl group on the sucrose moiety can be determined by changes in the chemical shift (δ) of the hydrogen and carbon atoms of the sucrose esters compared to sucrose. These changes in the δ may be observed by mono-dimensional NMR. For example, a shift of +0.5 ppm can be observed for the hydrogen atom which is in the α- position next to the acylated hydroxyl group. In addition, the directly acylated carbon and those next to it can undergo changes of ca. +1–2 ppm and ca. −2 ppm, respectively ( Huang et al., 2010 ; Li et al., 2008 ; Thévenet et al., 1999 ).

Furthermore, short-chain fatty acid such as isovaleric, isobutyric, tiglic and acetic acid were also found as substituents in NSEs. The NMR analysis showed δ for the hydrogen atoms on the methyl groups at approximately 0.9 ppm (doublet (d)) for isovaleric acid, approximately 1.2 and 1.3 ppm (d, for both cases) for isobutyric acid, approximately 2.0 ppm (s) for acetic acid and approximately 1.7 and 1.8 ppm (s and broad singlet (brs), respectively) for tiglic acid. The hydrogen atoms on the methylene group for the isovaleric acid showed δ at approximately 2.1 ppm (m). 13 C NMR analysis for the short-chain fatty acid showed δ for the CH 3 group at approximately 18.5 and 19.0 ppm for isobutyric, 22.3 ppm for isovaleric, 20.6 ppm for acetic, and 12.2 and 14.3 for tiglic acid. For latter acid, the quaternary and tertiary carbon atoms on the C = C group are observed at 129 ppm and 140 ppm, respectively ( Bernal et al., 2018 ; Pérez-Castorena et al., 2012 ; Zhang et al., 2016a , 2017 , 2016b ).

For the SEs with phenylpropanoid substituents, the main substituents found in these compounds are p -coumaric, benzoic, ferulic and cinnamic acids. The NMR analysis for the hydrogen atoms on the aromatic ring presents signals in the range of 6.0–9.0 ppm. The 1 H NMR analysis for the p -coumaric acid showed signals of characteristic δ for the p -hydroxyphenyl group at approximately 6.8 ppm (d, 2 H ) and approximately 7.5 ppm (d, 2 H ), and the trans- double-bond signal at 6.4 ppm (d) and 7.7 ppm (d). On the other hand, the hydrogen atoms signal for the –OCH 3 group on the ferulic acid is showed at a δ of 3.9 ppm (s). Also, the hydrogen atoms on the aromatic ring are observed at a δ of 7.5 (d) and 6.8 (d). The methoxy group on the aromatic ring is observed in the 13 C NMR at 56.5 ppm. The NMR analysis for NSEs with benzoic and cinnamic acid as substituents showed the signal of the hydrogen atoms on the aromatic ring at approximately δ 8.1 (d), 7.5 (d) and 7.6 ppm (d) ( Cho et al., 2015b ; Maier et al., 2015 ; Zhao et al., 2013 , 2014).

On the other hand, 1 H NMR analysis showed the signal characteristic of the disaccharide on the SEs. The hydrogen atom on the anomeric carbon of the α- D-glucopyranose ring (C-1) is observed in the range of 5.3 and 5.8 ppm (d). Other hydrogen atoms on the sucrose structure are observed between δH 3.4–4.2 ppm. The 13 C NMR analysis showed signal in the region of 60–110 ppm. The anomeric carbon of the β- D-fructofuranose (C-2′) is observed approximately at 102–105 ppm and the signal from the anomeric carbon of the α- D-glucopyranose is observed between 89 and 90 ppm ( El-Rokh et al., 2018 ; Huang et al., 2010 ; Pérez-Castorena et al., 2012 ; Zhang et al., 2016a ).

paragraph.emphasis: 5. Physiological properties of NSEs with aliphatic substitutes

subSection.paragraph:
Various plants species have been studied as sources of NSEs containing aliphatic substituents. However,
Physalis spp
,
Nicotiana tabacum (Solanaceae)
,
Equisetum hiemale (Equisetaceae)
and
Vernonia guineensis (Compositae)
are the ones which were extensively investigated in regard to extraction, chemical characterization and physiological effects of NSEs ( Table 1 ).

Different species of the genus
Physalis
from the Solanaceae family are used for the treatment of different diseases such as cancer, urinary problems and hepatitis. For example,
Physalis solanaceus ( Pérez-Castorena et al., 2012 )
,
Physalis peruviana
( Bernal et al., 2018 ; Franco et al., 2014 ),
Physalis alkekengi
var. Franchetiiv
( Zhang et al., 2016a , 2017 , 2016b ),
Physalis angulata
L ( Januário et al., 2002 ),
Physalis nicandroides var. Attenuata
( Maldonado et al., 2006 ),
Physalis viscosa ( Ovenden et al., 2005 )
,
Physalis philadelphica ( Zhang et al., 2016b )
and
Physalis sordida ( Pérez-Castorena et al., 2010 )
have been utilized for the treatment of various diseases. Generally, NSEs are extracted from fruits, leaves, aerial parts and calyces of
Physalis spp.
These compounds showed substitutions on the hydroxyl groups of C-2 and C-3’ with long-chain fatty acids such as lauric and capric acid. Also, short-chain fatty acids such as isovaleric, isobutyric, angelic or tiglic and acetic were also found as substituents. The physiological activity of these NSEs were suggest them as anti-inflammatory and antibacterial agents ( Table 1 ) ( Choi et al., 2006 ; Januário et al., 2002 ; Ji et al., 2012 ).

Other NSEs found in the fruits of
P. peruviana
( 4 and 5 ) ( Fig. 4 ) contain lauric and capric acids as substituents on the hydroxyl group of the C-2, respectively. Also, these fruits were reported as inhibitors of α- amylase enzymes, which provides the possible explanation for their hypoglycemic effect ( Bernal et al., 2018 ). In addition, in 2018, Cicchetti et al. (2018) extracted eight new NSEs ( 6–13 , Fig. 4 ). These NSEs are characterized by the presence of long-chain fatty acids (8–10 carbon atoms) as substituent on the hydroxyl group of the C-2, and short-chain fatty acid as substituent on the hydroxyl groups of the C-3, C-4, C-6 and C-3’. A crude extract with NSEs ( 6–9 ) was tested as a skin-aging biomarker in a normal aged human dermal fibroblast (NHDF) cell. The result showed cytotoxic activities for this extract at concentrations between 0.02 and 10 mg L −1 . However, 75% living cell threshold was reached at 2 mg L −1 .

NSEs isolated from the aerial parts of
P. alkekengi var. Franchetiiv
( 14–21 , Fig. 5 ) are characterized by different degrees of substitution with saturated and unsaturated carboxylic acids. These compounds have shown antibacterial activity on Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria such as
Staphylococcus aureus
,
Bacillus subtilis
,
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
,
Streptococcus pneumoniae
and
Escherichia coli
, with a minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) between 2 and 15 μg mL −1 ( Zhang et al., 2016a , 2017 , 2016b ). Although not expected, NSE with a long-chain fatty acid containing an odd number of carbons (13 carbons, 3′- O -tridecanoyl-2,3-di- O -tigloylsucrose) was isolated from
P. alkekengi var. franchetiiv ( Zhang et al., 2017 )
.

On the other hand, NSEs substituted with short-chain fatty acids ( 20 and 21 , Fig. 5 ) had less antibacterial activity. However, the 2- O -dodecanoyl-3- O -(2-methyl-2-butenoyl) sucrose extracted from
P. viscosa
( 22 ) ( Fig. 5 ) showed specific antibacterial activity for Gram-positive bacteria such as
S. aureus
and
S. pneumoniae ( Ovenden et al., 2005 )
.

subSection.paragraph: Zhao et al. (2015) showed that the size of the fatty acid chain influences the inhibitory action of the NSEs. Mono-SEs with stearic (18-C) and palmitic (16-C) acid as substituents did not inhibit Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, whereas, decreasing of the number of carbons of the fatty acid chain increased the antibacterial activity for the sucrose derivatives containing capric (10C), lauric (12C) and myristic acids (14C).

The aliphatic NSEs presented in
P. nicandroides var. attenuata
( 23–26 , Fig. 6 ) were found in higher concentrations in the resin covering the fruits than in other parts of the plant. Although, the specific physiological activity of these NSEs was not determined, it is suggested that these NSEs may act as protective agents to the fruit with insecticidal activity based on similar characteristics exhibited by other NSEs with similar structure ( Maldonado et al., 2006 ).

Other NSEs with different degrees of substitution isolated from
Physalis spp
containing lauric, decanoic and short carbon chain acids (isobutyric and acetic acid) were used as an anti-inflammatory agents ( 27–31) ( Fig. 6 ) ( Franco et al., 2014 ; Pérez-Castorena et al., 2010 ; Zhang et al., 2016b ). The 2- O -decanoyl-3,3′,4-tri- O -isobutanoyl sucrose ( 27 ) extracted from
P. peruviana
showed activity in reducing inflammation induced by λ- carrageenan (a sulfated polysaccharide used to generate and study models of inflammation and arthritic pain) by inhibiting the release or synthesis of nitric oxide (NO . ) and prostaglandin ( Franco et al., 2014 ). NSEs extracted from
P. philadelphica
( 28 and 29 ) showed inhibitory activity on cyclooxygenase enzymes, thus having similar effects with other drugs used for this purpose such as ibuprofen ( Zhang et al., 2016a , 2016b ).

subSection.paragraph:
Also, NSEs extracted from
P. sordida
( 30 and 31 , Fig. 6 ) were evaluated through a 12- O -tetradecanoylphorbol 13-acetate (TPA)-induced mouse ear edema test, obtaining IC 50 values (0.26 and 0.35 μmol ear −1 , respectively) similar to the inhibitory activity of indomethacin (reference compound, IC 50 0.24 μmol ear −1 ) ( Pérez-Castorena et al., 2010 ). Other studies have shown that NSEs substituted with saturated fatty acids do not have toxicological and genotoxic effects in mice, indicating the safety of these compounds for biological application as anti-inflammatory medicines administered parenterally ( Ocampo et al., 2017 ).

In general, the NSEs reported from
Nicotiana tabacum
are split into four types depending on the OH group substituted as observed in Fig. 7 . In these NSEs, the main substituent is a short-chain fatty acid (acetic acid) which vary in number and position in the sucrose (mainly on the C-6 and C-3’). Also, other short-chain fatty acid such as propionic, butyric, isobutyric, valeric, isovaleric, 3-methylvaleric, caproic or methylcaproic acid were found as acyl substituents in these NSEs mainly on the hydroxyl groups of C-2, C-3 or C-4 ( Ding et al., 2006 ; Zhu et al., 2013 ). However, the main type of aliphatic NSEs extracted from
N. tabacum
was identified as 6- O -acetyl-2,3,4-tri- O -acyl sucrose ( type I, 32 ) ( Ashraf-Khorassani et al., 2005 ; Simonovska et al., 2006 ).

Kandra et al. (1990) showed that the aliphatic substituent groups in the NSEs present in tobacco leaves are derived from biosynthetic routes of metabolites of branched-chain amino acids such as pyruvate and acetyl-CoA among others. This experimental observation is probably due to the low use of these compounds in the synthesis of proteins in specialized glandular head cells of trichomes. Other studies have also shown the importance of these NSEs since they have an inhibitory effect on some insects such as
Myzus persicae
, suggesting a protective role on tobacco leaves as biopesticides ( Chortyk et al., 1996 ; Simonovska et al., 2006 ).

On the other hand, plants of the specie
Baccharoides guineensis (Benth) (Compositae)
, also known as
Vernonia guineensis Benth
, are used in the treatment of diseases such as malaria ( Adia et al., 2014 ), bacterial infections ( Donfack et al., 2012 ) and helminthic infections ( Toyang et al., 2012a ). This specie of plant has also been used for the extraction of aliphatic NSEs ( Fig. 7 ).

The compounds ( 33 ) and ( 34 ) isolated from this specie of plant have five and four isovaleric acid as substituents, respectively, esterified on different hydroxyl groups in sucrose. Additionally, these NSEs were tested as antitumor agents in vitro against prostate cancer, and in ex vivo antiangiogenic activities using the rat ring aorta assay. These compounds also have antiplasmodial biological activity ( Toyang et al., 2013 , 2012b ).

Three mono-NSEs were extracted from
Equisetum hiemale
L. ( Equisetaceae ) ( 35–37 , Fig. 7 ). These sucrose derivatives had substitutions on the hydroxyl group of C-6’ with linolenic, hexadeca- 7,10,13-trienoic or hexadeca-7,10-dienoic acids. The cytotoxicity of these NSEs were tested against cell lines in vitro , however, all the NSEs were inactive ( Cheng et al., 2012 ).

paragraph.emphasis: 6. Physiological properties of NSEs with phenylpropanoid substitutes

subSection.paragraph:
NSEs with phenylpropanoid substituents have been identified in different plant genera such as
Bidens ( Wang et al., 2003 )
,
Prunus ( Zhao et al., 2014 )
,
Polygonum
( Kiem et al., 2008 ; Sun et al., 2000 ; Takasaki et al., 2001 ),
Quillaja ( Maier et al., 2015 )
,
Echium ( El-Rokh et al., 2018 )
,
Oryza
( Cho et al., 2015b ; Tian et al., 2004 ),
Phyllanthus
( Qian-Cutrone et al., 1996 ; Zhao et al., 2013 ),
Fagopyrum ( Liu et al., 2013 )
,
Bistorta

Extract of
Bidens parviflora (Compositae)
showed anti-inflammatory and antirheumatic activity ( Wang et al., 2006 ) due to the presence of the phenylpropanoid NSEs ( 38–40 , Fig. 8 ). These compounds showed inhibition of histamine release from rat mast cells and inhibition of prostaglandin production by macrophages stimulated by the antigenantibody reaction ( Wang et al., 2003 ). From this specie, an unusual phenylpropanoid sucrose ester was isolated ( 40 ), with the presence of a lignan moiety (bis(4-hydroxyphenyl) cyclobutanedicarboxyl group) as substituents.

The NSEs from
Phyllanthus cochinchinensis (Phyllanthaceae)
( 41–45, Fig. 8 ) are characterized by the presence of benzoic and cinnamoic acid on the hydroxyl group of C-6 or C-3’, and short-chain fatty acid (acetic acid) on the secondary hydroxyl group of the glucose unit as substituents. These compounds were tested against five human cancer cell lines, however, all the NSEs showed no cytotoxic activity at a concentration of 40 μM ( Zhao et al., 2013 ).

Cereals, of the specie
Oryza sativa
L . (Polaceae), is used in traditional Asian medicine for their anti-inflammatory ( Cho et al., 2015a ) and antitumor ( Miller et al., 2000 ) properties, among others. They were used for the isolation of NSEs with aromatic substituents. These natural phenylpropanoid SEs ( 46 and 47 , Fig. 8 ) can be produced by the phenolic metabolites of the seeds due to the high amount of carbohydrate and free phenolic compounds ( Miller et al., 2000 ; Tian et al., 2004 ). The presence of these NSEs could possibly explain the antioxidant properties of this type of cereal ( Tian et al., 2004 ). Other phenolic NSEs found in the roots of this cereal ( 48–50 , Fig. 8 ) showed the inhibitory activity of tyrosine, a precursor of the oxidation of phenolic compounds that is important for plant protection ( Cho et al., 2015b ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 12. NSEs extracted from
Prunus padus
,
Smilax glabra
,
Bistorta manshuriensis
and
Aristolochia cretica
.

subSection.paragraph:
Extracts of
Prunus tomentosa (Rosaceae)
fruits are used in Eastern traditional medicine for their anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, and are normally consumed in juices and also used in the manufacture of wines ( Liu et al., 2014 ). In this extract, 3-phenylpropanoid-triacetyl sucrose esters ( 51–54 , Fig. 9 ) were identified to exhibit antitumor activities in human cancer cells. The NSE ( 53 ) being the compound that attained the highest activity, with IC 50 of 0.11–0.62 μmol L
− 1
in the MCF-7, A 549, HeLa and HT-29 cancer cells. In addition, it has been determined that aliphatic substitutes in sucrose may play an important role in their cytotoxic characteristics, depending on their substitution positions in the molecule ( Zhao et al., 2014 ).

Two polysubstituted NSEs were extracted from
Polygonum lapathifolium (Polygonaceae)
( 55 and 56 , Fig. 9 ). These NSEs have three coumaroyl units as substituents on the hydroxyl groups of C-6, C-1′ and C-3’. Also, the NSEs 55 and 56 showed an additional coumaroyl and feruloyl unit on the hydroxyl group of C-6’, respectively. These NSEs showed inhibitory effects against the promotion stage of the two-stage carcinogenesis induced by TPA , with 90% and more than 60% inhibition at 1000 and 500 mol ratio/ TPA concentration, respectively ( Takasaki et al., 2001 ).

Another phenylpropanoid SEs extracted from
Polygonum perfoliatum (Polygonaceae)
( 57–60 , Fig. 9 ) had no reported physiological activity. However, these NSEs are characterized by the presence of two feruloyl units on the hydroxyl groups of C-3′ and C-6’, and the presence of three or four acetyl units as substituents ( Sun et al., 2000 ).

NSEs derived from dihydronaphthalene lignans ( 61 and 62 , Fig. 10 ), but extracted from
Echium angustifolium (Boraginaceae)
as amorphous powders, are compounds with in vitro anticancer activity in hepatocellular carcinoma (HepG2) and breast cancer (MCF7) cells, with morphological changes in cells treated with the inhibitor leading to IC 50 between 10 and 20 μg mL −1 ( El-Rokh et al., 2018 ). In comparison with the anticancer activity presented by the NSEs extracted from
Prunus tomentosa
, the NSEs 51–54 displayed higher cytotoxic activities when compared with NSEs 61 and 62 . This better activity can be associated with the presence of acetyl groups on sucrose, and by the increase of the lipophilicity of the NSEs. The latter increases with increasing number of acetyl groups in the molecule ( Saeed et al., 2010 ).

Extracts of
Quillaja Saponaria (Quillajaceae)
are used in the pharmaceutical, food and cosmetics industries due to their high saponin content ( Rodríguez-Díaz et al., 2011 ; San Martin and Briones, 1999 ). These extracts were studied for the isolation of NSEs with phenylpropanoid substituents. NSEs were identified with p -coumaroyl substituents that also have other carbohydrate units attached to sucrose ( 63 and 64 ) ( Fig. 10 ), showing high potential as antioxidant agents and as substrates for enzymatic browning reactions ( Maier et al., 2015 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 13. NSEs extracted from
Polygala sibirica
,
Polygala tenuifolia Willd
and Polygala glomerate.

subSection.paragraph:
Another p -coumaroyl NSE was identified in species of the genus
Fagopyrum acutatum (Polygonaceae)
( 66 , Fig. 11 ) which also has in its structure a ferulic substitute in the OH-6′ position. Its biological activity was determined by the inhibition of α- amylase, with IC 50 of 26.9 μmol L −1 . The aliphatic NSE extracted from
Physalis peruviana
showed α- amylase inhibition by up to 85% at 640 μg L −1 , however, the authors did not present the IC 50 values. On the other hand, the compound ( 66 ) can be used in the food industry in the control of postprandial hyperglycemia by mitigating the rate of starch digestion in the gastrointestinal tract ( Liu et al., 2013 ).

Aerial parts of
Bistorta manshuriensis (Polygonaceae)
, an important Korean medicinal plant, were used for the identification of natural feruloyl SEs ( 67–70 ) ( Fig. 12 ). These NSEs have in their structure a ferulic substitute on the position OH-6′ and OH-3’. For NSEs 67 and 68 , the biological activity is not yet reported ( Kim et al., 2010 ). However, the NSEs 69 and 70 , also extracted from other species of plants such as
Smilax bracteata (Smilacaceae)
( Panda et al., 2012 ), T rillium kamtschaticum ( Melianthaceae ) ( Ono et al., 2007 ) and
Paris polyphylla var. yunnanensis (Liliaceae)
( Yan et al., 2008 ), showed moderate antiproliferative and cytotoxic activities ( Panda et al., 2012 ; Yan et al., 2008 ).

Feruloyl SEs ( 71–76, Fig. 12 ) extracted from
Smilax bracteata (Smilacaceae)
showed biological activity as antioxidant agents, however, with moderate activities against 2,2-diphenyl-1-picryl-hydrazyl radical (DPPH). The NSE 71 presents an additional feruloyl unit on C-1′ when compared to other phenylpropanoid SEs ( 73–76 ), and showed higher antioxidant activity (DPPH) which indicates that the substitution degree play a crucial role in their antioxidant activity ( Zhang et al., 2008 ). Another natural phenylpropanoid SEs extracted from
Smilax glabra (Smilacaceae)
( 77–81 , Fig. 12 ), with no physiological activity reported, showed ferulic and coumaric acid as substituents on the hydroxyl group of C-1′, C-3′ and C-6’, and acetic acid on the different free hydroxyl group forming polysubstituted NSEs (Chen et al., 2000).

On the other hand, some natural phenylpropanoid SEs, with no physiological activity reported, were extracted from
Prunus padus (Rosaceae)
( 82–85, Fig. 12 ) ( Yoshinari et al., 1990 ) and
Aristolochia cretica (Aristolochiaceae)
( 86 and 87, Fig. 12 ) ( Georgopoulou et al., 2005 ). The NSEs ( 82–85 ) has a main structure of 3-
O -p-
coumaroyl sucrose and substituted in different position on the sucrose with acetyl group (short-chain fatty acid), producing natural polysubstituted SEs. In the NSE ( 87 ), the p -coumaroyl group is a substituent in the hydroxyl group on C-6. This SEs can be identified as a regioisomers of ( 46 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 14. NSEs extracted from
Polygala telephioides
and
Polygala arillate
.

Fig. 15. NSEs extracted from
Raphanus sativus , Calamus quiquesetinervius
and Canna edulis Ker Gawl.

subSection.paragraph:
Genera of plants of physiological interest such as
Polygala (Polygalaceae)
, known for its use as tonic, expectorant, and for preventing dementia in the traditional Chinese medicine, were used for the identification of natural phenylpropanoid SEs ( Figs. 13 and 14 ) ( Jiang et al., 2005 ; Miyase et al., 1999 ). NSEs were isolated from the roots of the some species of this family such as
Polygala sibirica
L ( 88–93 ) ( Miyase et al., 1999 ),
Polygala tenuifolia Willd
( 94 and 95 ) ( Jiang et al., 2005 ),
Polygala glomerata
( 96–102 ) ( Zhang et al., 1998 ),
Polygala telephioides
( 103–105 ) ( Chang and Tu, 2007 ),
Polygala arillate
( 106–111 )

( Kobayashi et al., 2000 ), and
Polygala japonica ( Zhang et al., 1996 )
. These NSEs are characterized by the presence of benzoic, hydroxybenzoic, sinapinic, ferulic and 3,4,5-trimethoxycinnamic acids, and acetic acid (short-chain fatty acid) as substituents in different positions on the sucrose. NSE 88 showed antioxidant activity in the DPPH (2,2- diphenylpicrylhydrazyl) free-radical scavenging test, with IC 50 5.0 mmol L −1 . However, its antioxidant activity in the DPPH test is lower when compared with sinapic and ascorbic acid, which are considered as a reference compound ( Fabre et al., 2000 ). Also, NSE 94 showed biological activity as antidepressant and NSE 95 showed neuroprotective and anti-apoptotic effects ( Dong et al., 2014 ; Hu et al., 2010 ).

Natural phenylpropanoid SEs with anti-inflammatory and antitumor activity ( 112–117 , Fig. 15 ) were extracted from the seeds of
Raphanus sativus (Brassicaceae)
, a common vegetable consumed in human diet and use in traditional Chinese medicine. These NSEs were identified as tri- and di-SEs with feruloyl, sinapoyl and 3,4,5-trimethoxycinnamoyl units as substituents on different hydroxyl groups of sucrose. Also, from this specie, the NSEs were extracted ( 93 ) and identified in the plant genus
Polygala
. The isolated NSEs ( 112–117 and 93 ) were investigated in lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-activated murine microglia BV-2 cells and tested as inhibitors of the production of nitric oxide ( NO ) (proinflammatory mediator). These NSEs showed anti-inflammatory activity, with IC 50 values <50 μmol L −1 Kim et al. (2015) ; ( Kiem et al., 2008 ).

Another NSEs with phenylpropanoid substituents ( 118–122 , Fig. 15 ) were isolated from
Calamus quiquesetinervius (Arecaceae)
. These NSEs showed coumaroyl and feruloyl units as substituents mainly on the hydroxyl group of C-3′, C-6’ and/or C-4 with different degree of substitutions, and presents acetyl unit on the hydroxyl group of C-6 or C-2. These NSEs were tested for their anti-inflammatory activity through the inhibition of the production of NO in RAW 264.7 cells. All NSEs demonstrate anti-inflammatory activity, however, NSEs 121 and 122 exhibited inhibition with IC 50 values <10 μmol L −1 . In comparison with the NSEs extracted from
Raphanus sativus
, NSEs 121 and 122 structurally showed acetyl and trans -coumaroyl units on the α- Dglucopyranosyl moiety and lower IC 50 values. Additionally, the NSEs extracted from
Raphanus sativus
and
Calamus quiquesetinervius
showed cytotoxic and antioxidant activities, respectively ( Chang et al., 2010 ; Kim et al., 2015 ).

Two natural phenylpropanoid SEs ( 123 and 124 , Fig. 15 ) were extracted from
Canna edulis Ker Gawl (Cannaceae)
, a plant used in traditional Vietnamese medicine. These NSEs present acetyl and p - coumaroyl units as substituents on the hydroxyl group of C-6 and C-3′, respectively. NSE 123 showed an additional coumaroyl unit as substituent on the hydroxyl group of C-6’, however, NSE 124 presents a feruloyl unit in the same position ( Sook Yun et al., 2004 ).

The physiological activity of different NSEs has been demonstrated with encouraging results. The nature of the substituent phenylpropanoid or aliphatic group changes the physiological observed effects, giving rise to a wide range of applications of these compounds in many chemical and pharmaceutical fields. For each class of NSEs, the type of organic acid substituents (aliphatic or phenylpropanoid), the substituent position, and the degree of esterification changes the physicochemical proprieties of the NSEs and, consequently, the biological activity. The lower concentration of NSEs makes extraction processes impracticable. This therefore opens a wide field in the development of undescribed chemical synthetic routes for these compounds. However, the reactivity control of sucrose and, principally, the degree and position of the substituents still a challenge.

document.paragraph: Jorge Andrés Mora Vargas is graduated in chemistry at Universidad Santiago de Cali , Colombia (2016), M.Sc. (2019) at the São Paulo State University at Institute of Biosciences, Humanities and Exact Sciences (IBILCE), Brazil and Ph.D student in chemistry at same institution under supervision of Prof. M. Boscolo. He was visiting student in the Centro de Investigación y Desarrollo Tecnológico en Electroquímica (CIDETEQ)” Queretaro-Mexico (2016), under supervision of Prof. C . Frontana. His research is focused on sugarcanebased raw chemicals (sucrose, fusel oil and ethanol) to obtain higher added-value compounds.

Julieth Orduña Ortega is graduated in chemistry at Universidad del Valle , Colombia (1999), M.Sc. (2006) at same institution and Ph.D student in chemistry at the São Paulo State University at Institute of Biosciences, Humanities and Exact Sciences (IBILCE), Brazil , under supervision of Prof. M. Boscolo. Her research experience has been developed in the use of advanced oxidation processes for the treatment of chemical residues, the use of biological treatments for the management of organic waste and biomass conversion into more added value products.

Gustavo Metzker is graduated in Chemistry at University of São Paulo , Chemistry Institute of São Carlos (2006), M. Sc. (2009) and Ph.D (2013) in Inorganic Chemistry at same institution. He was postdoctoral fellow at University of São Paulo , Chemistry Institute of São Carlos (2013–2017) under supervision of Prof. A . C . B . Burtoloso with 1-year period at University of California (Santa Barbara) under supervision of Prof. Peter C . Ford. Since 2017 he is postdoctoral fellow at São Paulo State University at Institute of Biosciences, Humanities and Exact Sciences (IBILCE) under supervision of Prof. M. Boscolo. His research interests are focused on biomass chemistry, mostly catalytic transformations of biomass into more added value products.

Jesús Eliecer Larrahondo is graduated in chemistry at Universidad del Valle , Colombia (1971), Ph.D. in chemistry at the Northeastern University, USA (1979). Professor of organic chemistry, phytochemistry and sucrochemistry. His was member of the committee of the international association of professionals in sugarcane and integrated sciences. He was a researcher and chief chemist at the Centro de Investigación en Caña de Azúcar (CENICAÑA), Colombia , for thirty years. He is a researcher and scientific advisor in the areas of phytochemistry, sucrochemistry and sugardairy processes.

Mauricio Boscolo
is graduated in Chemistry at University of São Paulo, Chemistry Institute of São Carlos (1994), M. Sc. (1996) and Ph.D (2001) in Analytical chemistry at same institution with a sandwich period of 1 year in the laboratory of Prof. Michele Aresta at the Università degli Studi di Bari , Italy (2000). He was postdoctoral fellow University of California, Santa Barbara (USA) under supervisor of Prof. Peter Ford on bioenergy related topics: new catalysts for lignin depolymerization by hydrogenolysis and supercritical catalytic hydrogenation. He was a Young FAPESP Research Fellow (2002–2004) developing a research project focused on the use of sucrose as a raw material for development of new chemical products (sucrochemistry). He is Associate Professor of the Department of Chemistry and
Environmental Sciences of the São Paulo State University at Institute of Biosciences,
Humanities and Exact Sciences (IBILCE). He was the first director of the Division of
Chemistry of Food and Beverages of the Brazilian Society of Chemistry (SBQ) from 2007
to 2008. He coordinates the Laboratory of sucrochemistry and Analytical Chemistry of
IBILCE-UNESP and integrates the Bioenergy Group of UNESP and the National Institute of
Science and Technology (INCT) of Bioethanol. His main research subjects are sucrochemistry, biofuels and catalysis.
